results.title: Cape Fear
results.creator_credit: John D. MacDonald, Barbara De Fina, Wesley Strick, Rita Ryack, Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro, Henry Bumstead, Tribeca Productions, Cappa Productions, Amblin Entertainment and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Sam Bowden is a small-town corporate attorney. Max Cady is a tattooed, cigar-smoking, bible-quoting, psychopath. Their worlds collide in this remake of the original by Martin Scorsese.

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.creator_credit_for_label: John D. MacDonald, Barbara De Fina, Wesley Strick, Rita Ryack, Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro, Henry Bumstead, Tribeca Productions, Cappa Productions, Amblin Entertainment and Universal Pictures
results.description: Sam Bowden is a small-town corporate attorney. Max Cady is a tattooed, cigar-smoking, bible-quoting, psychotic rapist. What do they have in common? Fourteen years ago, Sam was a public defender assigned to Max Cady’s rape trial, and he made a serious error: he hid a document from his illiterate client that could have gotten him acquitted. Now, the cagey, bibliophile Cady has been released, and he intends to teach Sam Bowden and his family a thing or two about loss.
description_for_label: Sam Bowden is a small-town corporate attorney. Max Cady is a tattooed, cigar-smoking, bible-quoting, psychotic rapist. What do they have in common? Now, the cagey, bibliophile Cady has been released, and he intends to teach Sam Bowden and his family a thing or two about loss.

results.title: Capacity Smith: the story of a successful dairy farmer
results.creator_credit: Colin Dean and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This early venture into docu-drama remains one of the government unit’s most successful, made with wit and skilful use of editing and music. The unlikely subject of scientific farm management is dramatised (using post-synchronised dialogue characteristic of the time) through the story of young Smith. Against the wishes of his father, but with his mother’s support, young Smith is permitted to study at the Hawkesbury Agricultural College. Returning home, he demonstrates to a sceptical father some of the benefits of modern methods of farming. Photographed by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: Capacitors
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Electrical Induction and Capacity”.
A brief summary of facts on electrostatics is followed by a demonstration of experiments with the Leyden jar; explanation of phenomenon in terms of build-up of charge; electroscope measurements when two charged plates are moved in relation to one another and when the dielectric is changed; capacitor or condensor factors affecting capacity; examples of capacitors at work.

results.title: Capability Brown
results.creator_credit: D.C. Chipperfield and Ransomes Film Unit
results.brief_description: The work of Lancelot Brown (1716-1793), the founder of the English style of landscape gardening, whose pioneering was, to a great extent, responsible for the very shape of the English countryside. Contrasts this with the formal French garden style, and looks at the great houses whose gardens were worked on by Brown - Longleat, Chatsworth House and Blenheim.

results.title: Canungra
results.creator_credit: Terry Ohlsson, Peter Johnson, Kingcroft Productions and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The origins of Canungra go back to 1942 when army headquarters ordered the formation of a jungle warfare training centre. Today the roles of the Land Warfare Centre have expanded to include the training of personnel of all Corps in Tactics and Administration, for land warfare and the development of associated doctrine, and equipment and operational techniques. (Marketing film aimed at recruitment for the Australian Army)

results.title: Canto a la Vida = Song to Life
results.creator_credit: Lucia Salinas Briones, Gina Roncoli and Vida Media Productions
results.brief_description: During the sixteen year dictatorship of General Augusto Pinochet that ended with the 1989 democratic elections, over one million Chileans left their homeland to live in exile. “Canto a la vida” explores the experience of living a life in exile through the stories of seven Chilean woman. They include Tencia de Allende, the widow of the murdered president Salvadore Allende; internationally renowned folk singer, Isabel Parra; author Isabel Allende and artist Gracia Barrios. Directed by Lucia Salinas Brionas who exiled to Australia in 1986. (English and Spanish with English subtitles)

results.title: Canticle of the stones = Cantique des pierres [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Michel Khleifi, Channel 4, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen, CBA, Radio Television Belge Francophone (RTBF) and Sourat Films
results.brief_description: Using a cinema verite format, Palestinian director, Michel Khleifi (Wedding in Galilee 1987, Tale of the three jewels 1994, Forbidden marriages in the Holy Land 1995) juxtaposes a fictional story of rekindled love with the confronting reality of violence and despair in the streets of occupied Palestine. The two lovers, now in their forties, have been separated for over 15 years after he was arrested and imprisoned by the Israelis for his part in the Palestinian Resistance and she, bitter and disappointed, decided to immigrate to America. On her arrival back to Jerusalem to study the Intifada’s impact on Palestinian society she discovers that he has been released from prison and it is against this background of resistance and repression that the two once again find love. This is a powerful film, combining fiction and reality through the use of poetic dialogue intertwined with the harsh and violent images of the occupation and resistance and in Khleifi’s own words…”By mixing elements of reality with a fictional love-story, my intention was to oppose the perception of the “Other” as a dispensable abstraction and to give expression to the pain and torment through which Palestinians were living”. Highly acclaimed, winner of two international awards and official selection for the 1990 Cannes Film Festival. Cinematography by Raymond Fromont. In Arabic with English subtitles.
results.title_for_label: Canticle of the stones = Cantique des pierres [Widescreen]

results.title: Canterbury: home of handweaving
results.brief_description: Hand weaving loom and spinning wheel manufacture in a Canterbury workshop. Shows the care and skill used in the production of these machines, each the work of one craftsman. At the Cathedral Weaving Centre, weavers can buy materials and learn the art of making fine hand-woven.
results.description: Hand weaving loom and spinning wheel manufacture in a Canterbury workshop. Shows the care and skill used in the production of these machines, each the work of one craftsman. At the Cathedral Weaving Centre, weavers can buy materials and learn the art of making fine hand-woven.

results.title: Canopy
results.credit_line:
John Harvey, Saibai Island

Multi-screen installation

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe
results.brief_description: John Harvey’s multi-screen installation, Canopy, celebrates and shares First Peoples self-representation while resisting and disrupting popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood too often defined by the white gaze of non-Indigenous filmmakers.

constellations_primary.name: Canopy
constellations_primary.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

results.description:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey
description_for_label:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey
